Continuous State Markov Chain Equilibrium

Aug 16, 2018 • Troy Stribling

A Markov Chain is a sequence of states where transitions between states occur ordered in time with the probability of transition depending only on the previous state. Here the states will be assumed a continuous unbounded set and time a discrete unbounded set. If the set of states is given by, x∈Rx\in\mathbb{R}x∈R, the probability that the process will be in state xxx at time ttt, denoted by πt(y)\pi_t (y)πt​(y), is referred to as the distribution. Markov Chain equilibrium is defined by limt→∞πt(y) < ∞\lim_{t\to\infty}\pi_t (y)\ <\ \inftylimt→∞​πt​(y) < ∞, that is, as time advances πt(y)\pi_t (y)πt​(y) becomes independent of time. Here a solution for this limit is discussed and illustrated with examples.

Model

The Markov Chain is constructed from the set of states {x}\{x\}{x}, ordered in time, where x∈Rx\in\mathbb{R}x∈R. The process starts at time t=0t=0t=0 with state X0=xX_0=xX0​=x. At the next step, t=1t=1t=1, the process will assume a state X1=yX_1=yX1​=y, y∈{x}y\in\{x\}y∈{x}, with probability P(X1=y∣X0=x)P(X_1=y|X_0=x)P(X1​=y∣X0​=x) since it will depend on the state at t=0t=0t=0 by the definition of a Markov Process. At the next time step t=2t=2t=2 the process state will be X2=z,where z∈{x}X_2=z, \text{where}\ z\in\{x\}X2​=z,where z∈{x} with probability, P(X2=z∣X0=x,X1=y)=P(X2=z∣X1=y), P(X_2=z|X_0=x, X_1=y) = P(X_2=z|X_1=y), P(X2​=z∣X0​=x,X1​=y)=P(X2​=z∣X1​=y), since by definition the probability of state transition depends only upon the state at the previous time step. For an arbitrary time the transition from a state Xt=xX_{t}=xXt​=x to a state Xt+1=yX_{t+1}=yXt+1​=y will occur with probability, P(Xt+1=y∣Xt=x)P(X_{t+1}=y|X_t=x)P(Xt+1​=y∣Xt​=x) that is independent of ttt. The Transition Kernel, defined by,

p(x,y)=P(Xt+1=y∣Xt=x), p(x,y) = P(X_{t+1}=y|X_t=x), p(x,y)=P(Xt+1​=y∣Xt​=x),

plays the same role as the transition matrix plays in the theory of Discrete State Markov Chains. In general p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y) cannot always be represented by a probability density function, but here it is assumed that it has a density function representation. This leads to the interpretation that for a known value of xxx p(x,y)p(x, y)p(x,y) can be interpreted as a conditional probability density for a transition to state yyy given that the process is in state xxx, namely,

p(x,y)=f(y∣x) p(x, y) = f(y|x) p(x,y)=f(y∣x)

Consequently, p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y) is a family of conditional probability distributions each representing conditioning on a possible state of the chain at time step ttt. Since p(x,y)p(x, y)p(x,y) is a conditional probability density for each value of xxx it follows that,

∫−∞∞p(x,y)dy=1 ∀ xp(x,y) ≥0 ∀ x, y     (1). \begin{gathered} \int^{\infty}_{-\infty} p(x, y) dy = 1\ \forall\ x \\ p(x,y)\ \geq 0\ \forall\ x,\ y \end{gathered}\ \ \ \ \ (1). ∫−∞∞​p(x,y)dy=1 ∀ xp(x,y) ≥0 ∀ x, y​     (1).

The transition kernel for a single step in the Markov Process is defined by p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y). The transition kernel across two time steps is computed as follows. Begin by denoting the process state at time ttt by Xt=xX_t=xXt​=x, the state at t+1t+1t+1 by Xt+1=yX_{t+1}=yXt+1​=y and the state at t+2t+2t+2 by Xt+2=zX_{t+2}=zXt+2​=z. Then the probability of transitioning to a state Xt+3=zX_{t+3}=zXt+3​=z from Xt=xX_{t}=xXt​=x in two steps, p2(x,z)p^2(x, z)p2(x,z), is given by, f(z∣x)=∫−∞∞f(z∣x,y)f(y∣x)dy=∫−∞∞f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dy=∫−∞∞p(y,z)p(x,y)dy=∫−∞∞p(x,y)p(y,z)dy \begin{aligned} f(z|x) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(z|x, y)f(y|x) dy \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(z|y)f(y|x) dy \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(y,z)p(x,y) dy \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x,y)p(y,z) dy \end{aligned} f(z∣x)​=∫−∞∞​f(z∣x,y)f(y∣x)dy=∫−∞∞​f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dy=∫−∞∞​p(y,z)p(x,y)dy=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)p(y,z)dy​

where use was made of the Law of Total Probability, in the first step and second step used the Markov Chain property f(z∣x,y)=f(z∣y)f(z|x, y)=f(z|y)f(z∣x,y)=f(z∣y). Now, the result obtained for the two step transition kernel is the continuous version of matrix multiplication of the single step transitions probabilities. A operator inspired by matrix multiplication would be helpful. Make the definition, P2(x,z)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)p(y,z)dy. P^2(x,z) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)p(y, z) dy. P2(x,z)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)p(y,z)dy.

Using this operator, with Xt+3=wX_{t+3}=wXt+3​=w, the three step transition kernel is given by, f(w∣x)=∫−∞∞f(w∣x,z)f(z∣x)dz=∫−∞∞f(w∣z)[∫−∞∞f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dy]dz=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞f(w∣z)f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dydz=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(z,w)p(y,z)p(x,y)dydz=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(x,y)p(y,z)p(z,w)dydz=P3(x,w), \begin{aligned} f(w|x) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(w|x,z)f(z|x) dz \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(w|z) \left[ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(z|y)f(y|x) dy \right] dz \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(w|z)f(z|y)f(y|x) dy dz \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z,w)p(y,z)p(x,y) dy dz \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x,y)p(y,z)p(z,w) dy dz \\ &= P^3(x,w), \end{aligned} f(w∣x)​=∫−∞∞​f(w∣x,z)f(z∣x)dz=∫−∞∞​f(w∣z)[∫−∞∞​f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dy]dz=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​f(w∣z)f(z∣y)f(y∣x)dydz=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(z,w)p(y,z)p(x,y)dydz=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(x,y)p(y,z)p(z,w)dydz=P3(x,w),​

where the second step substitutes the two step transition kernel and the remaining steps perform the decomposition to the single step transition kernel, p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y). Use of Mathematical Induction is used to show that the transition kernel between two states in an arbitrary number of steps, ttt, is given by,

Pt(x,y)=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞⋯∫−∞∞p(x,z1)p(z1,z2)…p(zt−1,y)dz1dz2…dzt−1. P^t(x,y) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\cdots\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x,z_1)p(z_1,z_2)\ldots p(z_{t-1},y) dz_1 dz_2\ldots dz_{t-1}. Pt(x,y)=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​⋯∫−∞∞​p(x,z1​)p(z1​,z2​)…p(zt−1​,y)dz1​dz2​…dzt−1​.

The distribution of Markov Chain states π(x)\pi (x)π(x) is defined by,

∫−∞∞π(x)dx=1π(x)≥0 ∀ x \begin{gathered} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \pi (x) dx = 1 \\ \pi (x) \geq 0\ \forall\ x \end{gathered} ∫−∞∞​π(x)dx=1π(x)≥0 ∀ x​

To determine the equilibrium distribution, πE(x)\pi_E (x)πE​(x), the time variability of πt(x)\pi_t (x)πt​(x) must be determined. Begin by considering an arbitrary distribution at t=0t=0t=0, π0(x)\pi_0 (x)π0​(x). The distribution after the first step will be,

π1(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)π0(x)dx. \pi_1 (y) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\pi_0 (x) dx. π1​(y)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)π0​(x)dx.

The distribution after two steps is,

π2(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)π1(x)dx=∫−∞∞p(x,y)[∫−∞∞p(z,x)π0(z)dz]dx=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(z,x)p(x,y)π0(z)dxdz \begin{aligned} \pi_2 (y) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\pi_1 (x) dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\left[ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z, x)\pi_0 (z) dz \right] dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z,x) p(x,y) \pi_0 (z) dx dz \end{aligned} π2​(y)​=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)π1​(x)dx=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)[∫−∞∞​p(z,x)π0​(z)dz]dx=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(z,x)p(x,y)π0​(z)dxdz​

The pattern becomes more apparent after the third step,

π3(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)π2(x)dx=∫−∞∞p(x,y)[∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(w,x)p(z,w)π0(z)dzdw]dx=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(x,y)p(w,x)p(z,w)π0(z)dzdwdx=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(z,w)p(w,x)p(x,y)π0(z)dwdxdz. \begin{aligned} \pi_3 (y) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\pi_2 (x) dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\left[ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(w,x) p(z,w)\pi_0 (z) dz dw \right] dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x,y) p(w,x) p(z,w)\pi_0 (z) dz dw dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z,w) p(w,x) p(x,y) \pi_0 (z) dw dx dz. \end{aligned} π3​(y)​=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)π2​(x)dx=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)[∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(w,x)p(z,w)π0​(z)dzdw]dx=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(x,y)p(w,x)p(z,w)π0​(z)dzdwdx=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(z,w)p(w,x)p(x,y)π0​(z)dwdxdz.​

This looks similar to the previous result obtained for the time dependence of the transition kernel. Making use of the operator PPP gives,

π1(y)=Pπ0(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)π0(x)dxπ2(y)=P2π0(y)=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(z,x)p(x,y)π0(z)dxdzπ3(y)=P3π0(y)=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞∫−∞∞p(z,w)p(w,x)p(x,y)π0(z)dwdxdz. \begin{aligned} \pi_1 (y) &= P\pi_0(y) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y)\pi_0 (x) dx \\ \pi_2 (y) &= P^2\pi_0(y) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z,x) p(x,y) \pi_0 (z) dx dz \\ \pi_3 (y) &= P^3\pi_0(y) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(z,w) p(w,x) p(x,y) \pi_0 (z) dw dx dz. \end{aligned} π1​(y)π2​(y)π3​(y)​=Pπ0​(y)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)π0​(x)dx=P2π0​(y)=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(z,x)p(x,y)π0​(z)dxdz=P3π0​(y)=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​p(z,w)p(w,x)p(x,y)π0​(z)dwdxdz.​

Mathematical Induction can be used to prove the distribution at an arbitrary time ttt is given by,

πt(y)=Ptπ0(y)     (2) \pi_t (y) = P^t\pi_0(y)\ \ \ \ \ (2) πt​(y)=Ptπ0​(y)     (2)

Equilibrium Distribution

The equilibrium distribution is defined as the invariant solution to equation (2)(2)(2) for arbitrary ttt, namely,

πE(y)=PtπE(y)     (3). \pi_E (y) = P^t\pi_E(y)\ \ \ \ \ (3). πE​(y)=PtπE​(y)     (3).

Consider, πE(y)=PπE(y)     (4), \pi_E (y) = P\pi_E(y)\ \ \ \ \ (4), πE​(y)=PπE​(y)     (4),

substitution into equation (3)(3)(3) gives,

πE(y)=PtπE(y)=Pt−1(PπE)(y)=Pt−1πE(y)⋮=PπE(y)=πE(y). \begin{aligned} \pi_E (y) &= P^t\pi_E(y) \\ &= P^{t-1}(P\pi_E)(y) \\ &= P^{t-1}\pi_E(y) \\ &\vdots \\ &= P\pi_E(y) \\ &= \pi_E(y). \end{aligned} πE​(y)​=PtπE​(y)=Pt−1(PπE​)(y)=Pt−1πE​(y)⋮=PπE​(y)=πE​(y).​

Thus equation (4)(4)(4) defines the time invariant solution to equation (3)(3)(3).

To go further a particular form for the transition kernel must be specified. Unlike the discrete state model a general solution cannot be obtained since convergence of the limit t→∞t\to\inftyt→∞ will depend on the assumed transition kernel. The following section will describe a solution to equation (4)(4)(4) arising from a simple stochastic processes.

Example

To evaluate the equilibrium distribution a form for the transition kernel must be assumed. Here the AR(1) stochastic process is considered. AR(1) is a simple first order autoregressive model providing an example of a continuous state Markov Chain. In following sections its equilibrium distribution is determined and the results of simulations are discussed.

AR(1) is defined by the difference equation,

Xt=αXt−1+εt     (5), X_{t} = \alpha X_{t-1} + \varepsilon_{t}\ \ \ \ \ (5), Xt​=αXt−1​+εt​     (5),

where t=0, 1, 2,…t=0,\ 1,\ 2,\ldotst=0, 1, 2,… and the εt\varepsilon{t}εt are identically distributed independent Normal\textbf{Normal}Normal random variables with zero mean and variance, σ2\sigma^2σ2. The ttt subscript on ε\varepsilonε indicates that it is generated at time step ttt. The transition kernel for AR(1) can be derived from equation (5)(5)(5) by using, εt∼Normal(0, σ2)\varepsilon_{t} \sim \textbf{Normal}(0,\ \sigma^2)εt​∼Normal(0, σ2) and letting x=xt−1x=x_{t-1}x=xt−1​ and y=xty=x_{t}y=xt​ so that εt=y−αx\varepsilon_{t} = y - \alpha xεt​=y−αx. The result is,

p(x,y)=12πσ2e(y−αx)2/2σ2      (6) p(x,y) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} e^{(y-\alpha x)^2/2\sigma^2}\ \ \ \ \ \ (6) p(x,y)=2πσ2​1​e(y−αx)2/2σ2      (6)

Now, consider a few steps,

X1=αX0+ε1X2=αX1+ε2X3=αX2+ε3, \begin{aligned} X_1 &= \alpha X_0 + \varepsilon_1 \\ X_2 &= \alpha X_1 + \varepsilon_2 \\ X_3 &= \alpha X_2 + \varepsilon_3, \end{aligned} X1​X2​X3​​=αX0​+ε1​=αX1​+ε2​=αX2​+ε3​,​

substituting the first equation into the second equation and that result into the third equation gives,

X3=α3X0+α2ε1+αε2+ε3 X_3 = \alpha^3 X_0 + \alpha^2\varepsilon_1 + \alpha\varepsilon_2 + \varepsilon_3 X3​=α3X0​+α2ε1​+αε2​+ε3​

If this process is continued for ttt steps the following result is obtained,

Xt=αtX0+∑i=1tαt−iεi     (7). X_t = \alpha^t X_0 + \sum_{i=1}^{t} \alpha^{t-i} \varepsilon_{i}\ \ \ \ \ (7). Xt​=αtX0​+i=1∑t​αt−iεi​     (7).

Equilibrium Solution

In this section equation (7)(7)(7) is used to evaluate the the mean and variance of the AR(1) process in the equilibrium limit t→∞t\to\inftyt→∞. The mean and variance obtained are then used to construct πE(x)\pi_E(x)πE​(x) that is shown to be a solution to equation (4)(4)(4).

The equilibrium mean is given by,

μE=limt→∞E(Xt). \mu_{E} = \lim_{t\to\infty} E(X_t). μE​=t→∞lim​E(Xt​).

From equation (7)(7)(7) it is seen that,

E(Xt)=E[αtX0+∑i=1tαt−iεi]=αtx0+∑i=1tE(εi)=αtx0, \begin{aligned} E(X_t) &= E\left[ \alpha^t X_0 + \sum_{i=1}^{t} \alpha^{t-i} \varepsilon_{i} \right] \\ &= \alpha^t x_0 + \sum_{i=1}^t E(\varepsilon_i) \\ &= \alpha^t x_0, \end{aligned} E(Xt​)​=E[αtX0​+i=1∑t​αt−iεi​]=αtx0​+i=1∑t​E(εi​)=αtx0​,​

where the last step follows from E(εi)=0E(\varepsilon_i)=0E(εi​)=0. Now,

μE=limt→∞E(Xt)=limt→∞αtX0, \begin{aligned} \mu_E &= \lim_{t\to\infty} E(X_t) \\ &= \lim_{t\to\infty} \alpha^t X_0, \end{aligned} μE​​=t→∞lim​E(Xt​)=t→∞lim​αtX0​,​

this limit exists for ∣α∣ ≤ 1\mid\alpha\mid\ \leq\ 1∣α∣ ≤ 1,

μE={X0∣α∣=10∣α∣ ≤ 1     (8). \mu_E = \begin{cases} X_0 & \mid\alpha\mid=1 \\ 0 & \mid\alpha\mid\ \leq\ 1 \end{cases}\ \ \ \ \ (8). μE​={X0​0​∣α∣=1∣α∣ ≤ 1​     (8).

The equilibrium variance is given by,

σE2=limt→∞E(Xt2)−[E(Xt)]2. \sigma^2_E = \lim_{t\to\infty} E(X^2_t) - \left[E(X_t)\right]^2. σE2​=t→∞lim​E(Xt2​)−[E(Xt​)]2.

To evaluate this expression and equation for Xt2X^2_tXt2​ is needed. From equation (7)(7)(7) it follows that,

Xt2=[αtX0+∑i=1tαt−iεi]2=α2tX02+2αtX0∑i=1tαt−1εi+∑i=1t∑j=1tαt−iαt−jεiεj. \begin{aligned} X_t^2 &= \left[ \alpha^t X_0 + \sum_{i=1}^{t} \alpha^{t-i} \varepsilon_i \right]^2 \\ &= \alpha^{2t}X_0^2 + 2\alpha^t X_0\sum_{i=1}^t \alpha^{t-1} \varepsilon_i + \sum_{i=1}^t \sum_{j=1}^t \alpha^{t-i}\alpha^{t-j}\varepsilon_i \varepsilon_j. \end{aligned} Xt2​​=[αtX0​+i=1∑t​αt−iεi​]2=α2tX02​+2αtX0​i=1∑t​αt−1εi​+i=1∑t​j=1∑t​αt−iαt−jεi​εj​.​

It follows that,

E(Xt2)=E[α2tX02+2αtX0∑i=1tαt−1εi+∑i=1t∑j=1tαt−iαt−jεiεj]=α2tX02+2αtX0∑i=1tαt−1E(εi)+∑i=1t∑j=1tαt−iαt−jE(εiεj)=α2tX02+∑i=1t∑j=1tαt−iαt−jE(εiεj), \begin{aligned} E(X_t^2) &= E\left[\alpha^{2t}X_0^2 + 2\alpha^t X_0\sum_{i=1}^t \alpha^{t-1} \varepsilon_i + \sum_{i=1}^t \sum_{j=1}^t \alpha^{t-i}\alpha^{t-j}\varepsilon_i \varepsilon_j \right] \\ &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + 2\alpha^t X_0\sum_{i=1}^t \alpha^{t-1} E(\varepsilon_i) + \sum_{i=1}^t \sum_{j=1}^t \alpha^{t-i}\alpha^{t-j}E(\varepsilon_i \varepsilon_j) \\ &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + \sum_{i=1}^t \sum_{j=1}^t \alpha^{t-i}\alpha^{t-j}E(\varepsilon_i \varepsilon_j), \end{aligned} E(Xt2​)​=E[α2tX02​+2αtX0​i=1∑t​αt−1εi​+i=1∑t​j=1∑t​αt−iαt−jεi​εj​]=α2tX02​+2αtX0​i=1∑t​αt−1E(εi​)+i=1∑t​j=1∑t​αt−iαt−jE(εi​εj​)=α2tX02​+i=1∑t​j=1∑t​αt−iαt−jE(εi​εj​),​

where the last step follows from E(εi)=0E(\varepsilon_i)=0E(εi​)=0. Since the εt\varepsilon_tεt​ are independent,

E(εiεj)=σ2δij, E(\varepsilon_i \varepsilon_j) = \sigma^2 \delta_{ij}, E(εi​εj​)=σ2δij​,

where δij\delta_{ij}δij​ is the Kronecker Delta, δij={0i≠j1i=j. \delta_{ij} = \begin{cases} 0 & i \neq j \\ 1 & i=j \end{cases}. δij​={01​i≠ji=j​.

Using these results gives,

E(Xt2)=α2tX02+σ2∑i=1t∑j=1tα2t−i−jδij=α2tX02+σ2∑i=1tα2(t−i)=α2tX02+σ2∑i=1t(α2)t−i=α2tX02+σ2[1−(α2)t−1]1−α2, \begin{aligned} E(X_t^2) &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + \sigma^2\sum_{i=1}^t \sum_{j=1}^t \alpha^{2t-i-j}\delta_{ij} \\ &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + \sigma^2\sum_{i=1}^t \alpha^{2(t-i)} \\ &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + \sigma^2\sum_{i=1}^t \left(\alpha^2\right)^{t-i} \\ &= \alpha^{2t} X_0^2 + \frac{\sigma^2\left[1 - (\alpha^2)^{t-1}\right]}{1 - \alpha^2}, \end{aligned} E(Xt2​)​=α2tX02​+σ2i=1∑t​j=1∑t​α2t−i−jδij​=α2tX02​+σ2i=1∑t​α2(t−i)=α2tX02​+σ2i=1∑t​(α2)t−i=α2tX02​+1−α2σ2[1−(α2)t−1]​,​

The last step follows from summation of a geometric series,

∑i=1t(α2)t−1=∑k=0t−1(α2)k=1−(α2)t−11−α2. \begin{aligned} \sum_{i=1}^{t} (\alpha^2)^{t-1} &= \sum_{k=0}^{t-1}(\alpha^2)^k \\ &= \frac{1-(\alpha^2)^{t-1}}{1-\alpha^2}. \end{aligned} i=1∑t​(α2)t−1​=k=0∑t−1​(α2)k=1−α21−(α2)t−1​.​

In the limit t→∞t\to\infty t→∞ E(Xt2)E(X_t^2)E(Xt2​) only converges for ∣α∣ < 1\mid\alpha\mid\ <\ 1∣α∣ < 1. If α=1\alpha=1α=1 the denominator of the second term in of E(Xt2)E(X_t^2)E(Xt2​) is 000 E(Xt2)E(X_t^2)E(Xt2​) is undefined. σE2\sigma^2_EσE2​ is evaluated assuming ∣α∣ < 1\mid\alpha\mid\ <\ 1∣α∣ < 1 if this is the case (8)(8)(8) gives μE=0\mu_E=0μE​=0, so,

σE2=limt→∞E(Xt2)−(μE)2=limt→∞α2tX02+σ2[1−(α2)t−1]1−α2=σ21−α2.     (9) \begin{aligned} \sigma^2_E &= \lim_{t\to\infty} E(X_t^2) - \left(\mu_E\right)^2 \\ &= \lim_{t\to\infty} \alpha^{2t}X_0^2 + \frac{\sigma^2\left[1 - (\alpha^2)^{t-1}\right]}{1 - \alpha^2} \\ &= \frac{\sigma^2}{1 - \alpha^2}. \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (9) σE2​​=t→∞lim​E(Xt2​)−(μE​)2=t→∞lim​α2tX02​+1−α2σ2[1−(α2)t−1]​=1−α2σ2​.​     (9)

The equilibrium distribution, πE\pi_EπE​, is found by substituting the results from equation (8)(8)(8) and (9)(9)(9) into a Normal(μE, σE2)\textbf{Normal}(\mu_E,\ \sigma^2_E)Normal(μE​, σE2​) distribution to obtain,

πE(y)=12πσE2e−y2/2σE2     (10) \pi_E(y) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}}e^{-y^2/2\sigma_E^2}\ \ \ \ \ (10) πE​(y)=2πσE2​​1​e−y2/2σE2​     (10)

It can be shown that equation (10)(10)(10) is the equilibrium distribution by verifying that it is a solution to equation (4)(4)(4). Inserting equations (6)(6)(6) and (10)(10)(10) into equation (4)(4)(4) yields,

PπE(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)πE(x)dx=∫−∞∞[12πσ2e(y−αx)2/2σ2][12πσE2e−y2/2σE2]dx=12πσ212πσE2∫−∞∞e−12[(y−αx)2/σ2+x2/σE2]dx=12πσ212πσE2∫−∞∞e−12[y2/σE2+(x−αy)2/σ2]dx=12πσE2e−y2/2σE212πσ2∫−∞∞e−(x−αy)2/2σ2dx=12πσE2e−y2/2σE2=πE(y) \begin{aligned} P\pi_E(y) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y) \pi_E(x) dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} e^{(y-\alpha x)^2/2\sigma^2}\right]\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}}e^{-y^2/2\sigma_E^2}\right] dx \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left[(y-\alpha x)^2/\sigma^2+x^2/\sigma_E^2 \right]} dx \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left[y^2/\sigma_E^2+(x-\alpha y)^2/\sigma^2 \right]} dx \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}} e^{-y^2/2\sigma_E^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-(x-\alpha y)^2/2\sigma^2} dx \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_E^2}} e^{-y^2/2\sigma_E^2} \\ &= \pi_E(y) \end{aligned} PπE​(y)​=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)πE​(x)dx=∫−∞∞​[2πσ2​1​e(y−αx)2/2σ2][2πσE2​​1​e−y2/2σE2​]dx=2πσ2​1​2πσE2​​1​∫−∞∞​e−21​[(y−αx)2/σ2+x2/σE2​]dx=2πσ2​1​2πσE2​​1​∫−∞∞​e−21​[y2/σE2​+(x−αy)2/σ2]dx=2πσE2​​1​e−y2/2σE2​2πσ2​1​∫−∞∞​e−(x−αy)2/2σ2dx=2πσE2​​1​e−y2/2σE2​=πE​(y)​

Simulation

An AR(1) simulator can be implemented using either the difference equation definition, equation (5)(5)(5) or the transition kernel, equation (6)(6)(6). The result produced by either are statistically identical, An example implementation in Python using equation (5)(5)(5) is shown below.

def ar_1_difference_series(α, σ, x0, nsample=100):
    samples = numpy.zeros(nsample)
    ε = numpy.random.normal(0.0, σ, nsample)
    samples[0] = x0
    for i in range(1, nsample):
        samples[i] = α * samples[i-1] + ε[i]
    return samples

The function ar_1_difference_series(α, σ, x0, nsamples) takes four arguments: α and σ, the initial value of xxx, x0 and the number of desired samples nsample. It begins by allocating storage for the sample output followed by generation of nsample values of εt∼Normal(0, σ2)\varepsilon_t\sim \textbf{Normal}(0,\ \sigma^2)εt​∼Normal(0, σ2) with the requested standard deviation, σ\sigmaσ. The samples are then created using the AR(1) difference equation. A second implementation using the transition kernel, equation (6)(6)(6) is shown below.

def ar1_kernel_series(α, σ, x0, nsample=100):
    samples = numpy.zeros(nsample)
    samples[0] = x0
    for i in range(1, nsample):
        samples[i] = numpy.random.normal(α * samples[i-1], σ)
    return samples

The function ar1_kernel_seriesar1_kernel_series(α, σ, x0, nsamples) also takes four arguments: α and σ, the initial value of xxx, x0 and the number of desired samples nsample. It begins by allocating storage for the sample output and then generates samples using the transition kernel with distribution Normal(α∗samples[i−1], σ2)\textbf{Normal}(α * samples[i-1],\ \sigma^2)Normal(α∗samples[i−1], σ2).

The plots below show examples of time series generated using ar_1_difference_series with σ=1\sigma=1σ=1 for values of α < 1\alpha\ <\ 1α < 1. It is seen that for smaller α\alphaα values the series more frequently changes direction and have smaller variance. This is expected from equation (9)(9)(9), where σE=1/1−α2\sigma_E=1/1-\alpha^2σE​=1/1−α2.

If α\alphaα is just slightly larger than 111 the time series can increase rapidly as illustrated in the plot below.

For α < 1\alpha\ <\ 1α < 1 σE\sigma_EσE​ is bounded and the generated samples are constrained about the equilibrium mean value, μE=0\mu_E=0μE​=0, but for α ≥ 1\alpha\ \geq\ 1α ≥ 1 σE\sigma_EσE​ is unbounded and the samples very quickly develop very large deviations from μE\mu_EμE​.

Convergence to Equilibrium

For sufficiently large times samples generated by the AR(1) process will approach the equilibrium values for α < 1\alpha\ <\ 1α < 1. In the plots following the cumulative values of both the mean and standard deviation computed from simulations, using ar_1_difference_series with σ=1\sigma=1σ=1, are compared with the equilibrium vales μE\mu_EμE​ and σE\sigma_EσE​ from equations (8)(8)(8) and (9)(9)(9) respectively. The first plot illustrates the convergence μ\muμ to μE\mu_EμE​ for six different simulations with varying initial states, X0X_0X0​, and α\alphaα. The rate of convergence is seen to decrease as α\alphaα increases. For smaller α\alphaα the simulation μ\muμ is close to μE\mu_EμE​ within 10210^2102 samples and indistinguishable from μE\mu_EμE​ by 10310^3103. For larger values of α\alphaα the convergence is mush slower. After 10510^5105 samples there are still noticeable oscillations of the sampled μ\muμ about μE\mu_EμE​.

Since σE\sigma_EσE​ varies with α\alphaα for clarity only simulations with varying α\alphaα are shown. The rate of convergence σ\sigmaσ to σE\sigma_EσE​ is slightly slower than the rate seem for μ\muμ. For smaller α\alphaα simulation σ\sigmaσ computations are indistinguishable form σE\sigma_EσE​ by 10310^3103 samples. For larger α\alphaα after 10410^4104 sample deviations about the σE\sigma_EσE​ are still visible.

The plot below favorably compares the histogram produced from results of a simulation of 10610^6106 samples and the equilibrium distribution, πE(y)\pi_E(y)πE​(y), from equation (10)(10)(10).

A more efficient method of estimating πE(y)\pi_E(y)πE​(y) is obtained from equation (4)(4)(4) by noting that for sufficiently large number of samples equation (4)(4)(4) can be approximated by the expectation of the transition kernel, namely,

πE(y)=PπE(y)=∫−∞∞p(x,y)πE(x)dx≈1N∑i=0N−1p(xi,y).     (11) \begin{aligned} \pi_E(y) &= P\pi_E(y) \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} p(x, y) \pi_E(x) dx \\ &\approx \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=0}^{N-1} p(x_i, y). \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (11) πE​(y)​=PπE​(y)=∫−∞∞​p(x,y)πE​(x)dx≈N1​i=0∑N−1​p(xi​,y).​     (11)

A Python implementation of the solution to equation (11)(11)(11) for the average transition kernel is listed below where two functions are defined.

def ar_1_kernel(α, σ, x, y):
    p = numpy.zeros(len(y))
    for i in range(0, len(y)):
        ε  = ((y[i] -  α * x)**2) / (2.0 * σ**2)
        p[i] = numpy.exp(-ε) / numpy.sqrt(2 * numpy.pi * σ**2)
    return p

def ar_1_equilibrium_distributions(α, σ, x0, y, nsample=100):
    py = [ar_1_kernel(α, σ, x, y) for x in ar_1_difference_series(α, σ, x0, nsample)]
    pavg = [py[0]]
    for i in range(1, len(py)):
        pavg.append((py[i] + i * pavg[i-1]) / (i + 1))
    return pavg

The first function ar_1_kernel(α, σ, x, y) computes the transition kernel for a range of values and takes four arguments as input: α and σ from equation (5)(5)(5) and the value of x and an array of y values where the transition kernel is evaluated. The second function ar_1_equilibrium_distributions(α, σ, x0, y, nsample) has five arguments as input:
α and σ, the initial value of xxx, x0, the array of y values used to evaluate the transition kernel and the number of desired samples nsample. ar_1_equilibrium_distributions begins by calling ar_1_difference_series to generate nsample samples of x. These values and the needed inputs are then passed to ar_1_kernel providing nsample evaluations of the transition kernel. The cumulative average of the transition kernel is then evaluated and returned.

In practice this method gives reasonable results for as few as 10210^2102 samples. This is illustrated in the following plot where the transition kernel mean value computed with just 505050 samples using ar_1_equilibrium_distributions is compared πE(y)\pi_E(y)πE​(y) from equation (10)(10)(10).

The following plot shows intermediate values the calculation in the range of 111 to 505050 samples. This illustrates the changes in the estimated equilibrium distribution as the calculation progresses. By 500500500 samples a distribution near the equilibrium distribution is obtained.

Conclusions

An overview of the properties of Markov Chain equilibrium for continuous state processes has ben given. Equations defining the equilibrium transition kernel and distribution were derived. These equations were solved for the AR(1) stochastic processes in the limit t→∞{t\to\infty}t→∞. The analytic results were shown to agree with simulations.
